title: 111_hr4390
content: The Act is titled the "Medicare and Medicaid Fraud Prevention and Control Act of 2009" and includes enhanced program and provider protections in the Medicare, Medicaid, and CHIP programs. The Secretary may impose enhanced oversight measures if there is a significant risk of fraudulent activity with a category of provider or supplier under Medicare, Medicaid, or CHIP programs. The Secretary may impose requirements on providers or suppliers enrolling in Medicare, Medicaid, or CHIP programs, including screening, enhanced oversight periods, enrollment moratoria, and periodic validations of authorizations. The Secretary may impose requirements on providers enrolling in Medicare, Medicaid, or CHIP programs, including screening, enhanced oversight periods, enrollment moratoria, and periodic validations of authorizations. States may be required to implement these provisions as part of their state plans. Actions and determinations made under these provisions are not subject to judicial review. The Secretary may establish screening procedures for providers enrolling in Medicare, Medicaid, or CHIP programs, including licensing board checks, screening against exclusion lists, background checks, site visits, and heightened disclosure of affiliations. Judicial review does not apply to these provisions. The Secretary may establish enhanced oversight procedures for providers enrolling in Medicare, Medicaid, or CHIP programs, including site visits, inspections, prepayment review, and enhanced claims review for a period of 30 to 365 days. The Secretary may extend oversight period for more than 365 days if necessary, including enhanced review for DME suppliers with significant fraud risk. The Secretary may withhold payment for durable medical equipment supplied by a supplier identified for excessive prescribing. A program will be established for periodic review of physician authorizations in cases of potential excessive prescribing. The Secretary may withhold payment for durable medical equipment supplied by a supplier identified for excessive prescribing. A program will be established for periodic review of physician authorizations in cases of potential excessive prescribing. If a physician or health care professional is identified for excessive prescribing, they will receive a quarterly list of claims based on their prescriptions. If they do not validate the legitimacy of these claims within 90 days, payment for related items and services may be withheld. The Secretary may impose a moratorium on enrollment of providers and suppliers in cases of serious fraud risk within Medicare, Medicaid, or CHIP programs. This is done to validate claims for items and services prescribed by physicians or professionals, and payment may be withheld if legitimacy is not confirmed within 90 days. The Secretary can impose a moratorium on provider enrollment to prevent fraud in Medicare, Medicaid, or CHIP programs. This is to ensure the legitimacy of claims for services and items, with payment withheld if legitimacy is not confirmed within 90 days. States can conduct additional provider screening beyond federal requirements. The Secretary can impose a probationary period for new providers and suppliers in Medicare, Medicaid, or CHIP programs to validate the legitimacy of their operations and claims. This period includes heightened review of claims and physician prescriptions for up to 1 year. The Secretary can suspend or terminate a provider or supplier's participation in Medicare, Medicaid, or CHIP programs if a significant number of claims are deemed illegitimate after validation of physician prescriptions or authorizations. This action follows a probationary period for new providers and suppliers to ensure the legitimacy of their operations. The Secretary may suspend or terminate a provider's participation in Medicare, Medicaid, or CHIP programs for illegitimate claims after validation of prescriptions. Failure to cooperate may result in a civil monetary penalty of up to $10,000. Amendments are made to prompt pay provisions in certain sections of the Act. Amendments are made to prompt pay provisions in certain sections of the Act, including the exclusion of claims from providers or suppliers showing suspicious patterns of fraudulent behavior. Amendments to the Social Security Act include provisions to address fraudulent behavior, such as enforcing determinations made by the Secretary under subsection (a). Amendments to the Social Security Act include provisions for States to enforce determinations made by the Secretary regarding fraudulent activity in provider categories. Additionally, State child health plans must outline procedures for program integrity. Amendments to the Social Security Act require States to enforce Secretary's determinations on fraudulent activity in provider categories. State child health plans must detail procedures for program integrity. Amendments to the Social Security Act require consultation with the Inspector General for identifying fraudulent activity in provider categories under Medicare. The Secretary of Health and Human Services consults with the Inspector General to identify providers or services at risk of fraud under Medicare, Medicaid, or the State children's health insurance program. Additional funding may be appropriated for this purpose. The amendments made by this section will take effect upon the enactment of the Act. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will issue regulations within 6 months to implement the changes. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will issue regulations within 6 months of the Act's enactment, with an interim final regulation effective immediately upon publication. Public comments will be allowed, and revisions may be made after the comment period.
